instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related study to propose an advanced regression model based on the extreme learning machine (ELM) algorithm for quantitative chemometric analysis?
Output: In the related study, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR) was used to acquire the experimental data.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were employed in the related study to propose an advanced regression model based on the extreme learning machine (ELM) algorithm for quantitative chemometric analysis?
Output: An ELM-based autoencoder (AE) was developed for reducing the dimensionality of spectral signals and learning important features for regression.

instruction: Which metric was chosen to evaluate the performance of the proposed model in the related study to propose an advanced regression model based on the extreme learning machine (ELM) algorithm for quantitative chemometric analysis, and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the performance of the proposed model in the related study was RMSE (root mean square error). The RMSE can go as low as 0 for well-performing regression models.

instruction: What is the main objective of the proposed chemometrics model based on the extreme learning machine (ELM) algorithm in this study?
Output: The main objective of the proposed chemometrics model based on the extreme learning machine (ELM) algorithm in this study is to provide a rapid and reliable method for quantitative analysis of physical and/or chemical components in complex gas mixtures using infrared (IR) spectroscopic/sensing techniques.

instruction: Can the proposed chemometrics model based on the ELM algorithm be used to determine physical and/or chemical components in complex gas mixtures using infrared (IR) spectroscopic/sensing techniques?
Output: Yes, the proposed chemometrics model based on the extreme learning machine (ELM) algorithm can be used to determine physical and/or chemical components in complex gas mixtures using infrared (IR) spectroscopic/sensing techniques. The model utilizes an ELM-based autoencoder (AE) to reduce the dimensionality of spectral signals and learn important features for regression. It also directly utilizes the fast regression ability of the ELM architecture to construct the regression model. The model has been tested and verified using both simulated data and experimental data acquired using Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (FTIR), specifically analyzing nitrogen oxide mixtures found in vehicle exhaust. The results of the analysis showed that the proposed model offers superior robustness and performance compared to conventional principle components regression (PCR) and partial least square regression (PLSR) models in quantitative IR spectral analysis.
